natural problem: 23 people attend a party. Each person shakes hands with at most 22 other people. What is the maximum possible number of handshakes, assuming that any two people can shake hands at most once?
natural solution: Note that if each person shakes hands with every other person, then the number of handshakes is maximized. There are $\binom{23}{2} = \frac{(23)(22)}{2} = (23)(11) = 230+23 = \boxed{253}$ ways to choose two people to form a handshake.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 22 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> j. i * j = n - 1)"
shows  "max_handshakes = 253"
where "max_handshakes = (\<Sum>i \<le> 22. i)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 23 people attend a party. Each person shakes hands with at most 22 other people. What is the maximum possible number of handshakes, assuming that any two people can shake hands at most once? The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Note that if each person shakes hands with every other person, then the number of handshakes is maximized. There are $\binom{23}{2} = \frac{(23)(22)}{2} = (23)(11) = 230+23 = \boxed{253}$ ways to choose two people to form a handshake.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 22 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> j. i * j = n - 1)"
shows  "max_handshakes = 253"
where "max_handshakes = (\<Sum>i \<le> 22. i)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 23 people in a room. If each person shakes hands with all the others exactly once, find the total number of handshakes that will take place. The final answer is 253.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "handshakes = (\<lambda>n. n * (n - 1) div 2)"
shows  "handshakes n = 253"
a_1.formal solution:

 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "handshakes = (\<lambda>n. n * (n - 1) div 2)"
shows  "handshakes n = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If there are 23 people in a room and each person shakes hands with every other person exactly once, how many handshakes will there be? The final answer is 253.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "\<forall>p. p \<in> {0..22} \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>q. q \<in> {0..22} \<longrightarrow> (p \<noteq> q \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>hs. hs \<in> {1..253})))"
shows  "card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {0..22} \<and> q \<in> {0..22} \<and> p \<noteq> q} = 253"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 23 people attend a party. Each person shakes hands with at most 22 other people. What is the maximum possible number of handshakes, assuming that any two people can shake hands at most once? The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Note that if each person shakes hands with every other person, then the number of handshakes is maximized. There are $\binom{23}{2} = \frac{(23)(22)}{2} = (23)(11) = 230+23 = \boxed{253}$ ways to choose two people to form a handshake.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
and h1 : "\<forall>p. p \<in> {0..22} \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>q. q \<in> {0..22} \<longrightarrow> (p \<noteq> q \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>hs. hs \<in> {1..253})))"
shows  "card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {0..22} \<and> q \<in> {0..22} \<and> p \<noteq> q} = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 23 distinct elements in a set, numbered from 0 to 22. How many unique pairs of distinct elements can be formed from this set? The final answer is 253.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes handshakes people :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 23"
and h1 : "handshakes \<le> people * (people - 1) div 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> i j. i < people \<and> j < people \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> handshakes \<ge> 1"
shows  "handshakes = 253"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 23 people attend a party. Each person shakes hands with at most 22 other people. What is the maximum possible number of handshakes, assuming that any two people can shake hands at most once? The final Answer is 253
 ### Proof
 Note that if each person shakes hands with every other person, then the number of handshakes is maximized. There are $\binom{23}{2} = \frac{(23)(22)}{2} = (23)(11) = 230+23 = \boxed{253}$ ways to choose two people to form a handshake.
 *)

theorem
fixes handshakes people :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 23"
and h1 : "handshakes \<le> people * (people - 1) div 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> i j. i < people \<and> j < people \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> handshakes \<ge> 1"
shows  "handshakes = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a group of 23 people, each person shakes hands with every other person exactly once. How many handshakes take place in total? The final answer is 253.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
shows  "Max {n * (n - 1) div 2 | n. n \<le> 22} = 253"
a_7.formal solution:

 *)

fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 23"
shows  "Max {n * (n - 1) div 2 | n. n \<le> 22} = 253"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the maximum value of the expression $n * (n - 1) \div 2$ for all natural numbers $n$ less than or equal to 22. The final answer is 253.
